Comment: My usual opening.
Introducing the Sicilian defense, one of the best answers to 1.e4. The idea is to play cxd4 when white play d4.
Preparing 3.d4 cxd4 4.Nxd4.
This move is important to prevent white from playing e5 after black plays Nf6. It also opens the h3-c8 diagonal for LSB.
Controlling the center.
Threatening the e4 pawn and developing a piece.
Threatening the e4 pawn and developing a piece.
Threatening the e4 pawn and developing a piece.
Protecting the e4 pawn and developing a piece.
This is the Sicilian Najdorf defense. 5...a6 is played to prevent white from playing Nb5 or Bb5. It also prepares a minority attack by b5.
The main line. It threatens to double black's pawn on the f-file. It also prepare O-O-O after queen moves.
To avoid a doubled pawns on the f-file.
Allowing 8.e5 pinning the f6 knight.
Attacks the b2 pawn. Usually this opening leads to a very complicated positions. Safer is 7...Nbd7, 7...Be7 or 7...Qc7.
Now, this is the Sicilian Najdorf Poisoned pawn variation. White allows black to capture a pawn or more to have an open game and dangerous attack.
Forced.
Forced.
Forced.
More plyable is 10.f5.

17...h6? G/K analyse didn't comment on this move. However, i think this is the losing move. It allows white to attack the queen and then putting pressure on black's king. Best in my openion is 17...Bc5! 18.Nxc5 Qxe3+ 19.Bxe3 Nxc5 20.Rg4 Nd7 21.Rxg7 with a draw.
